text: [Music]
[Applause]
[Music]
hello I'm ratna A Cloud support engineer
at the AWS office in Dallas today I'm
going to show you how to resolve errors
received for a failing Amazon cloudwatch
Canary created in your virtual private
Cloud let's get started the first step
to resolve a failing VPC Canary is to
identify the exact error these are the
type of Errors you can receive no test
results returned connection timed out
after 30 000 milliseconds and no
artifacts were uploaded timeout error
navigation timeout exceeded 30 000
milliseconds exceeded let's dive into
how to troubleshoot the error no test
results returned connection timed out
after 30 000 milliseconds and no
artifacts were uploaded when you create
a canary in a VPC and AWS Lambda
function with an elastic network
interface is created in the specified
VPC subnets these elastic network
interfaces have no public IP addresses
by default even if they were added to
public subnets
after logging in to the AWS Management
console navigate to the cloudwatch
console
choose the region where you have the
failing Canary I'm going to select UST
one
then select synthetic skinaries from the
left navigation pane under application
monitoring
the page shows all the canaries under
this account in the selected region
choose the failing VPC Canary
under the issues tab you can see the
error the canary failed with
if you see the error no artifacts were
uploaded or no test result returned then
the canary wasn't able to send data to
Amazon's simple storage service and
cloudwatch after each Canary run the
canary uploads its artifacts to Amazon
S3 and publishes metrics to cloudwatch
choose the configuration tab and scroll
down to the VPC settings
copy the VPC ID associated with the
canary
scenario number one the VPC has a public
subnet a subnet in the VPC has a route
to an internet gateway open the VPC
console and then select subnets
search with the VPC ID and then check if
the subnets have an internet gateway
if any of the subnets have an internet
gateway that indicates that the VPC has
internet connectivity
next check the subnet that's associated
with the canary
check the route table of the subnet and
check if it has an ad Gateway if it
doesn't then the canary doesn't have
internet access
if the subnet has an internet gateway
then the canary doesn't have internet
access because the Lambda function of
the canary doesn't have a public IP in
this case we must associate the canary
with the private subnet with an ad
Gateway
now let's explore scenario number two
the VPC has only private subnets if no
Subnet in the VPC has a route table with
a route to an internet gateway then the
VPC does not have internet connectivity
in this scenario the VPC needs private
access to S3 and cloudwatch using VPC
endpoints navigate to VPC endpoints Tab
and make sure you have a S3 endpoint and
monitoring endpoint associated with the
canary VPC
then you must make sure that the
security group associated with the
canary allows outbound https traffic
Amazon S3 and cloudwatch monitoring
endpoints are reachable through https
now let's see how we can troubleshoot
timeout error navigation timeout
exceeded 30 000 milliseconds exceeded
error we must confirm that the security
groups and network ACLS are allowing
traffic to your endpoint
we must check the amount of time that
the endpoint takes to respond to do that
use the following command
after you confirm the time taken you
must also edit the canary script timeout
to correspond to your endpoint
make sure that the timeout value in your
script is less than the default Canary
timeout or the frequency of the canary
run
now you know how to resolve errors
received for a failing cloudwatch Canary
created in your bpc
thanks for watching and happy cloud
computing from all of us here at AWS
[Music]
[Applause]
[Music]
[Music]
